Text:
The recent outbreak of cholera in Zimbabwe which is spreading across the nation with over 800 cases and five deaths reflects the country's collapsed healthacre system and poor infrastructure development.
It also shows the dilapidation of water and sanitation systems in a country mired in economic decay and crisis for decades.
Inadequate access to water and poor sanitation infrastructure are a major source of health risks and deadly disease outbreaks such as cholera. 
Poor and inadequate water and sanitation is a leading cause of poverty, morbidity (disease and illness) and mortality (deaths) in Zimbabwe.
The first recorded cholera case was on 12 February 2023 with the disease now rampaging across all the country's 10 administrative provinces. 
As at 13 April 2023, 436 suspected cholera cases had been reported, two laboratory confirmed deaths, seven suspected deaths and 88 confirmed cases.
Now there have been 834 cholera cases and five deaths, showing a seriously deteriorating situation.
The largest cholera outbreak in Zimbabwe occurred between August 2008 and July 2009, with 98 592 cases and 4288 deaths recorded.

Text:
Hammanskraal residents demand justice for cholera deaths linked to water tender scandal and DAâs incompetence
The water tender scandal has resurfaced amid a cholera outbreak in Hammanskraal that has claimed at least 15 lives and left many more in critical condition. 
The outbreak has been attributed to the poor quality of water supplied by the City of Tshwane. The former ANC-led City of Tshwane awarded a R295 million water tender to a joint venture that included businessman Edwin Sodi, who is facing corruption charges for another project.
A whistleblower and an inquiry revealed that the tender was corrupt and that the progress on the water treatment plant was limited. The former ANC-led city has not accounted for the funds or faced any legal action. The current DA-led city, under Mayor Cilliers Brink, has also failed to address the water crisis and prevent the cholera outbreak that has killed 15 people in Hammanskraal.
ð¥ð - Jubilee Hospital in Hammanskraal, Tshwane. 
âªï¸ #MamelodiBeacon

Text:
Tshwane mayor refuses to drink Hammanskraal water after EFF challenge
Tshwane mayor Cilliers Brink has declined to drink a glass of water that the EFF stated was from Hammanskraal, where a cholera outbreak has killed at least 17 people. The EFF disrupted a special council meeting on Wednesday, where Finance MMC Peter Sutton was supposed to table the budget speech for the 2023/2024 financial year. The EFF councillors entered the chamber with a bottle of dirty and brownish water, demanding that Brink and Speaker Mncedi Ndzwanana drink it first before the meeting could proceed.
EFF regional leader Obakeng Ramabodu said they were protesting in solidarity with the residents of Hammanskraal, who have been suffering from poor water quality and sanitation for years. He accused the DA-led administration of failing to address the water crisis and causing the cholera outbreak. âWe have brought water from Hammanskraal because you are saying there's no cholera. Drink it, let's see,â he said.
Brink refused to drink the water, saying that he did not trust the source or the authenticity of the bottle. He said that the city was working hard to improve the water situation in Hammanskraal, and that it had allocated R450 million for the refurbishment of the Rooiwal Wastewater Treatment Works. He also slammed the EFF for politicising the issue and disrupting the council meeting.
Brink criticised the commission of inquiry into the Hammanskraal water woes, initiated by Herman Mashaba's ActionSA party, as a political stunt. He said that he would not participate in the commission, which he described as illegitimate and biased. He said that the city was cooperating with the provincial and national health authorities to contain and prevent further spread of cholera.
The council meeting was adjourned after several attempts by Ndzwanana to restore order failed. The EFF vowed to continue their protest until their demands were met.

âªï¸ #MamelodiBeacon

Text:
The first case of cholera was traced to a tap that was contaminated with raw sewage.
An Anglican priest, Henry Whitehead was the assistant curate of St Lukeâs Church in Soho, London, in 1854. Soho at that time was known for its criminals and slums. Sanitation was poor. But this was also a time before the germ theory of disease had been developed, and people generally believed that disease was spread through miasma, or polluted air. Henry Whitehead agreed with this theory. 
In 1854, a cholera epidemic broke out in Soho near St Lukeâs. At that time, there was no cure, and the mortality rate was around 60%. A physician, John Snow, believed â correctly â that the miasma theory was baseless and that cholera was waterborne. His investigation took him to St Lukeâs, which was where he encountered Whitehead â who was determined to prove him wrong.
ï¿¼
Whitehead and Snow traced the outbreak back to a single tap.
This meeting turned out to have huge significance. Snowâs work was pioneering in the field of epidemiology, but he lacked local knowledge to trace the spread of cholera through the community. Whitehead, as priest, was deeply embedded in the community, and his parishioners came to him for aid. Despite their opposing viewpoints, the men agreed to collaborate, and between them traced all of the outbreaks of cholera back to a single water pump, which turned out to have been contaminated by sewage. This contributed to changes in Londonâs water system, the foundation of epidemiology, and the eradication of cholera in the developed world. And while Snow got to have his theory proven right and has been widely honoured, Whitebread simply continued to be a parish priest.

Text:

Text:
Cholera crisis exposes rift between Mbeki and Ramaphosa on governance and water issues
The #CholeraOutbreak in Hammanskraal has raised concerns about the quality of governance and water management in South Africa. Former President Mbeki criticized the national leadership for being unresponsive to the people's needs and suggested a revolt as a solution.
However, President Ramaphosa expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and praised the authorities for their swift actions. He also acknowledged the long-standing problem of poor water quality in Hammanskraal and said that legal action was taken against the City of Tshwane to upgrade the waste water treatment works. 
He stressed the need to focus on stopping the spread of cholera and ensuring safe water for all. He also said that water quality in South Africa was generally high and that the ministry of Water and Sanitation would make recommendations to improve municipal water management.

Text:
Dr. Sharif Yahaya Musa is a district-level public health specialist in Nigeria.

Ahead of Teach to Reach 8, he shared his experience in response to the question: Have you used Oral Cholera Vaccine (OCV) during a cholera outbreak?

âYes, in my setting, the biggest challenge is inadequate OCV where only few LGAs got the vaccines and they got only one dose instead of two due to shortage of it in the country.

We reported to the national regarding the issue and they responded by saying that the issue is a global shortage.

The strategy used was to vaccinate children 1-5 years in two doses.

The challenge for integrating cholera treatment was inadequate drugs and consumables.

Due to the shortage, we were unable to do the second dose.

There was support by some organizations like UNICEF in water hygiene and sanitation project, but it was not enough.

Regarding the outbreak, it occurred in some LGAs but it was contained.

An Information Managemnet System (IMS) was inaugurated for the response and we got support from many partners, which drastically assisted in curtailing the situation. In the end, the number of deaths was negligible.â

Have you used Oral Cholera Vaccine (OCV) during a cholera outbreak? If so, share your experience in the comments.

Join Dr. Sharif Yahaya Musa and more than 15,000 health professionals who will be sharing their experience in tackling their most difficult immunization challenges at Teach to Reach. Follow this link to request your invitation https://t.co/6zdGK6pP7K

Text:
CHOLERA

Cholera is an acute diarrheal disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. It is typically spread through contaminated water or food. Cholera is most common in areas with poor sanitation, particularly in parts of Africa and currently in Hammanskraal

Text:
Cholera crisis exposes rift between Mbeki and Ramaphosa on governance and water issues
The #CholeraOutbreak in Hammanskraal has raised concerns about the quality of governance and water management in South Africa. Former President Mbeki criticized the national leadership for being unresponsive to the people's needs and suggested a revolt as a solution.
However, President Ramaphosa expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and praised the authorities for their swift actions. He also acknowledged the long-standing problem of poor water quality in Hammanskraal and said that legal action was taken against the City of Tshwane to upgrade the waste water treatment works. 
He stressed the need to focus on stopping the spread of cholera and ensuring safe water for all. He also said that water quality in South Africa was generally high and that the ministry of Water and Sanitation would make recommendations to improve municipal water management.
âªï¸ #MamelodiBeacon

Text:
BREAKING NEWS | Six people die in Hammanskraal due to gastroenteritis outbreak
A gastroenteritis outbreak in Hammanskraal, north of Pretoria, has resulted in the deaths of six people. While more than 50 patients have received care at Jubilee Hospital in Hammanskraal.
Gastroenteritis is a common and often highly infectious condition that affects the stomach and intestines. It mostly spreads by contact with an infected person or through contaminated food and drinking water sources. Common symptoms include diarrhoea, cramps, nausea, vomiting and low-grade fever.
The National Health Department has warned the public of the outbreak of the diarrhoeal disease and urged them to take extra precautionary measures and maintain proper hand hygiene. The department also said that cases of cholera are on the rise, with four more cases confirmed in Gauteng and seven in Vredefort and Parys in the Free State.
The provincial and district outbreak teams in both provinces are in the areas to investigate the source and extent of the infections. The department said it will provide updates on the situation as more information becomes available.
âªï¸#MamelodiBeacon

Text:
Hammanskraal residents demand justice for cholera deaths linked to water tender scandal and DAâs incompetence
The water tender scandal has resurfaced amid a cholera outbreak in Hammanskraal that has claimed at least 15 lives and left many more in critical condition. 
The outbreak has been attributed to the poor quality of water supplied by the City of Tshwane. The former ANC-led City of Tshwane awarded a R295 million water tender to a joint venture that included businessman Edwin Sodi, who is facing corruption charges for another project.
A whistleblower and an inquiry revealed that the tender was corrupt and that the progress on the water treatment plant was limited. The former ANC-led city has not accounted for the funds or faced any legal action. The current DA-led city, under Mayor Cilliers Brink, has also failed to address the water crisis and prevent the cholera outbreak that has killed 15 people in Hammanskraal.

Text:
Tshwane mayor refuses to drink Hammanskraal water after EFF challenge
Tshwane mayor Cilliers Brink has declined to drink a glass of water that the EFF stated was from Hammanskraal, where a cholera outbreak has killed at least 17 people. The EFF disrupted a special council meeting on Wednesday, where Finance MMC Peter Sutton was supposed to table the budget speech for the 2023/2024 financial year. The EFF councillors entered the chamber with a bottle of dirty and brownish water, demanding that Brink and Speaker Mncedi Ndzwanana drink it first before the meeting could proceed.
EFF regional leader Obakeng Ramabodu said they were protesting in solidarity with the residents of Hammanskraal, who have been suffering from poor water quality and sanitation for years. He accused the DA-led administration of failing to address the water crisis and causing the cholera outbreak. âWe have brought water from Hammanskraal because you are saying there's no cholera. Drink it, let's see,â he said.
Brink refused to drink the water, saying that he did not trust the source or the authenticity of the bottle. He said that the city was working hard to improve the water situation in Hammanskraal, and that it had allocated R450 million for the refurbishment of the Rooiwal Wastewater Treatment Works. He also slammed the EFF for politicising the issue and disrupting the council meeting.
Brink criticised the commission of inquiry into the Hammanskraal water woes, initiated by Herman Mashaba's ActionSA party, as a political stunt. He said that he would not participate in the commission, which he described as illegitimate and biased. He said that the city was cooperating with the provincial and national health authorities to contain and prevent further spread of cholera.
The council meeting was adjourned after several attempts by Ndzwanana to restore order failed. The EFF vowed to continue their protest until their demands were met.

Text:
Cholera crisis exposes rift between Mbeki and Ramaphosa on governance and water issues
The #CholeraOutbreak in Hammanskraal has raised concerns about the quality of governance and water management in South Africa. Former President Mbeki criticized the national leadership for being unresponsive to the people's needs and suggested a revolt as a solution.
However, President Ramaphosa expressed his condolences to the families of the victims and praised the authorities for their swift actions. He also acknowledged the long-standing problem of poor water quality in Hammanskraal and said that legal action was taken against the City of Tshwane to upgrade the waste water treatment works. 
He stressed the need to focus on stopping the spread of cholera and ensuring safe water for all. He also said that water quality in South Africa was generally high and that the ministry of Water and Sanitation would make recommendations to improve municipal water management.
âªï¸ #MamelodiBeacon
